entries.name: Spinosaurus mirabilis
entries.temporalRange: Late Cretaceous (Cenomanian), about 95 million years ago
entries.location: Farak Formation, Niger (localities: Iguidi and Jenguebi)
entries.overview: Spinosaurus mirabilis is a named species-level interpretation within Spinosaurus, described from cranial and postcranial remains from Niger. Current interpretation emphasizes a long, low snout, a prominent scimitar-like cranial crest, and elongated neural spines that indicate a dorsal sail.

sections.title: Discovery and naming
sections.text: Fossils referred to Spinosaurus mirabilis were collected from outcrops of the Farak Formation in Niger during expeditions in 2000, 2019, and 2022 led by Paul Sereno and colleagues. Material came from two principal localities, Iguidi and Jenguebi. The species was formally described in 2026 and assigned to Spinosaurus based on a combined cranial and postcranial diagnosis. The name mirabilis (Latin, "astonishing") references the unusually enlarged scimitar-like nasal-prefrontal crest.

sections.title: Holotype and referred specimens
sections.text: The holotype, MNBH JEN1, includes a fragmentary skull preserving right premaxilla, both maxillae, crest elements, part of the right dentary, and associated teeth. Referred specimen MNBH JEN2 includes additional maxillary material, crest fragments, cervical and dorsal vertebral pieces, part of the left ischium, and part of the femur. Additional Jenguebi specimens (MNBH JEN3-9) and Iguidi material (including MNBH IGU11, 25, and 38-40) expand the sample with isolated teeth, vertebral fragments, and limb/tail elements.

sections.title: Taxonomic history of key Niger material
sections.text: Some Niger specimens now referred to S. mirabilis had a complex assignment history before the 2026 revision. Certain vertebral elements were previously compared with carcharodontosaurid material and later discussed as indeterminate spinosaurid remains or alternative spinosaurine assignments. The 2026 diagnosis unified these remains under S. mirabilis using crest morphology, rostral proportions, and associated axial anatomy as the central lines of evidence.

sections.title: Anatomical diagnosis
sections.text: Spinosaurus mirabilis is interpreted as having a relatively low-profile snout, distinctive dentary-premaxillary contour relationships, and posterior maxillary spacing differences compared with S. aegyptiacus. Preserved dorsal elements support elongated neural spines consistent with a trunk sail, although complete sail outline remains uncertain due to incomplete serial preservation.

sections.title: Cranial crest and display interpretation
sections.text: Its most distinctive feature is the scimitar-shaped crest formed by nasal and prefrontal bones. Surface vascular traces and striations are consistent with soft-tissue enhancement in life, possibly a keratinous covering. Functional interpretation currently favors visual signaling (species recognition, social display, maturity signaling), with purely mechanical interpretations considered secondary.

sections.title: Comparison with Spinosaurus aegyptiacus
sections.text: Compared with S. aegyptiacus, S. mirabilis appears to differ in crest geometry, some jaw-proportion metrics, and rostral profile. Both taxa share core spinosaurine traits such as elongate jaws and neural-spine development, but current datasets support species-level separation. Because several elements are still fragmentary, future specimens may refine the strength or polarity of some proposed differences.

sections.title: Phylogenetic placement
sections.text: Current analyses recover S. mirabilis within Spinosaurini as the closest sampled relative of S. aegyptiacus. This placement supports keeping both species in Spinosaurus rather than splitting into separate genera. Stability of this placement depends on future matrix expansion and additional overlapping cranial/postcranial material.

sections.title: Open research questions
sections.text: High-priority questions include adult size range, degree of intraspecific crest variation, and the extent to which currently referred specimens represent one versus multiple local populations. Future work combining CT imaging, broader stratigraphic sampling, and specimen-level morphometric datasets will be essential for testing species boundaries and functional interpretation.
